Situation1: They participate in a national continuing education program to maintain licensure and expertise in the latest treatments.
Expectation2: Attend meetings and court sessions punctually
Situation2: They are expected at routine meetings that occur frequently
Story: I sat at my desk, the glow of my laptop screen illuminating the stack of continuing education modules I needed to complete for my pharmacist license. The national program was rigorous this year, packed with updates on new therapies and safety protocols. My supervisor expected me to stay at the forefront of pharmaceutical knowledge, and I took pride in being a reliable resource for my patients. But as I scrolled through the next module, my phone buzzed—a reminder for the advocacy meeting scheduled in fifteen minutes. As an advocate, I was counted on to be present and punctual at every meeting and court session, to give a voice to those who needed it most. I glanced at the clock, feeling the pressure mount. If I left now, I’d miss the live Q&A with the program’s lead instructor, a rare chance to clarify complex topics. But if I stayed, I’d be late to the meeting, letting down the people who depended on my support. My heart pounded as I weighed the expectations pressing in from both sides, torn between my commitment to professional excellence and my responsibility to those I represented.
